Km 107 Carretera Tijuana-Ensenada Apdo Postal 14 Ensenada Baja California CP 22800 Mexico Enzyme-mimetic materials such as Fe-containing zeolites are of research interest due to the high selectivity for the one-step selective oxidation of benzene to phenol over the Fe-catalytic active center at room temperature and ambient pressure. This study investigates a Fe-modified Y zeolite catalysts prepared via a sonochemical method for the oxidation of benzene-to-phenol using water as solvent. These catalysts were subjected to a screening and optimization experiment by a response surface methodology (RSM), evaluating their potential for the synthesis of phenol. Achieving the preparation of a catalyst with an increased phenol selectivity from 3 % to ∼91 % and almost 100 % when evaluated at 30 ºC. Various Fe species, including the α-Fe(II) active site, were detected using UV-Vis spectroscopy, FTIR spectroscopy, and magnetic thermal gravimetric analysis (MTGA). Highlighting the potential of sonochemistry for preparing at mild temperatures (<100 ºC) iron-modified zeolite Y catalysts with room temperature catalytic active in water-based systems. Graphical Abstract Keywords Sonochemistry Catalysis Zeolite Iron Benzene Phenol Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Zeolites are aluminosilicates formed by tetrahedrally coordinated atoms linked through bridging oxygen atoms and forming porous structures. More than 250 different structures, both natural and artificial, have been described. One such material is the faujasite (FAU, according to the unique three-letter code assigned to each of the topologically distinct zeolites by the International Zeolite Association, IZA [1], a naturally occurring zeolite discovered in basaltic rocks [2] and later synthesized in the laboratory [3]. Zeolites with the FAU structure are currently the most commercially used catalysts for fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) [4] and in ion exchange processes [5]. FAUs have shown great catalytic potential when modified with rare earth elements and transition metals [6]. One of the most commonly used metals due to its availability and catalytic potential is iron (Fe) since it has been seen to have the ability to catalyze different reactions, such as oxidative [7] and C-C coupling of 2-naphthol [8], functionalization of 2-naphthols [9], indole trimerization, synthesis of isatins [10], alcohol-amine coupling reactions [11], Suzuki−Miyaura cross-coupling [12], H2 production, hydrocracking of plastic waste, oxy dehydration of glycerol, glycerol hydrogenolysis, synthesis of biofuel additives from glycerol [13], cracking of 1,3,5-triisopropylbenzene [14], dye degradation, degradation of ceftriaxone, synthesis of perimidine derivatives, hydrolysis of polysaccharide [15], lactose hydrolysis [16], oxidation of dioxane, styrene, cyclohexene, limonene [17], decomposition of N2O [18], deNOx selective catalytic reaction process [19] phenol [20] and benzene hydroxylation [21], to name a few. This latter reaction has drawn attention since the three-step cumene process produces 90 % of phenol (a value-added product) from benzene (a carcinogenic contaminant). The disadvantage of this method is the simultaneous production of ketones, which need to be separated since phenol is employed as a precursor molecule widely used for the chemical synthesis of nylon-66, various polymers, and pharmaceuticals [22,23]. However, Fe-containing zeolites have proven to be enzyme-mimetic materials as a consequence of possessing Fe-active sites with high selectivity at room temperature and pressure for the partial oxidation of benzene to phenol (POBP) [22,24]. Research has been carried out on generating a one-step process for the selective oxidation of benzene-to-phenol employing several materials, including Fe-containing zeolites, under the influence of different oxidants H2O2, N2O, O2 and H2 in acetonitrile or water solutions [25]. Among the most studied Fe-zeolite for the selective hydroxylation of benzene to phenol is N2O-activated Fe-ZSM-5, the active site of which is characterized as an extra-lattice active site called α-Fe(II), which is activated by nitrous oxide and heat (above 300 ºC) to form a reactive intermediate α-O [26–29]. Nevertheless, Fe-ZSM-5 is not the only zeolite that can stabilize α-Fe, this active site is also found in BEA, FER, CHA and FAU (zeolites with six-member rings, 6MR) [30]. Therefore, theoretical calculations and simulations for the structural configuration of α-Fe/O were employed, although only ZSM-5, FER, CHA and BEA were considered [31–37], where BEA was the most promising material selected for the experimental research on the hydroxylation of benzene to phenol [38]. The creation of α-O through the decomposition of N2O is a reaction that also takes place above 300 ºC for Fe-FAU [39]. However, α-Fe was detected in a series of Fe-FAU zeolites prepared by a sono-assisted method at 60 ºC [16], and in addition to the evidence that Fe-exchanged FAU can produce phenol [21] suggests that these samples prepared by sono-assisted method could catalyze the POBP, creating Fe based zeolitic catalysts that are active at relatively low temperatures. Due to simplicity, an ideal catalyst should catalyze any reaction, including the oxidation of benzene to phenol in water, with air as the oxidant, at room temperature and ambient pressure. This reaction was tested with a Fe-based non-zeolitic catalyst in water with H2O2 as the oxidant, successfully hydroxylating benzene to phenol with side products such as catechol, resorcinol, hydroquinone, and benzoquinone, all of which are hydroxylated phenol products [40]. As expected, a Fe-Y zeolite catalyst under the same conditions (water and H2O2 as an oxidant) also hydroxylated phenol [20]. When evaluating the source of oxygen in phenol, replacing the solvent for acetonitrile with H2O2 as the oxidant proved that the oxygen atom in phenol comes from H2O2 [41]. However, this study evidenced that using H2O2 as an oxidant decreases phenol selectivity by promoting phenol hydroxylation. When this reaction was tested in water with air and a non-zeolitic photocatalyst, the oxidation of benzene to phenol was catalyzed with high selectivity, showing that the oxygen source of phenol is water [42], indicating that high selectivity for the POBP can be obtained in a water-based environment. Considering the interest in the Fe-FAU system, and also taking into account the fact that the flexibility of the properties of zeolite supports makes it possible to easily modify materials prepared on their basis, and the complex chemistry of iron oxides-hydroxides, we can conclude that this system still needs further investigation. The only well-studied catalytically active site in Fe zeolite is the α-Fe/α-O site, which is involved in the low-temperature POBP [43]. It is necessary not only to distinguish between the types of iron species present and the precise active sites for specific reactions [44], but also to select conditions for their reproducible preparation. Modification of Y zeolite with Fe species using the sono-assisted method is proposed to develop more homogeneous, reproducible, and selective conditions for the preparation of specific active Fe sites to stabilize iron species in a zeolite [19]. In this work, commercial Y zeolite was modified with iron by a sonochemical method, and the catalytic properties of the resulting materials in the POBP in an aqueous medium with water as an oxidant at room temperature and ambient pressure were assessed. 2 Experimental (materials and methods) 2.1 Sono-assisted modification with Fe Materials and reagents used in this work include commercial faujasite in ammonium form with a nominal Si/Al ratio of 2.6, typical for Y-zeolite (CBV 500, NH4-Y, USY), provided by Zeolyst International, and FeSO4 (Cat. No. 215422), Fe2(SO4)3 (Cat. No. 307718), NH4OH (Cat. No. 05002), and HNO3 (Cat. No. 225711) from Sigma Aldrich. Faujasite Y was modified with iron in two steps. Since zeolites are excellent ion exchangers, attempts to precipitate Fe species using ultrasonic irradiation on the initial zeolite would lead to competition between two processes - ion exchange and precipitation. Therefore, first, zeolite Y zeolite was stirred in a 0.23 M FeSO4 solution to perform routine ion exchange acidified with HNO3 to pH 3 to saturate its exchange capacity, with three times the theoretical cation exchange capacity of iron ions and with a solid/liquid ratio of 1/20, for two hours at 80 °C’; the resulting material is named FeY. This Fe-exchanged zeolite (FeY) was then used to deposit different types of Fe species. In brief, 2 g of FeY was suspended in an NH4NO3 buffer solution at pH 5 and sonicated for 30 min at 60 °C, with the addition of 132 µL of 0.5 M FeSO4 (FeII) and 62 µL of 1 M Fe2(SO4)3 (FeIII) immediately after starting sonication. The final concentration of Fe ions added to the zeolitic suspension was 1 wt% of Fe with a molar ratio of 1:1 (II/III) of divalent (Fe2+) and trivalent (Fe3+) Fe ions, naming this sample as FeYII/III. After the process, all materials were filtered and washed with excess water until a stable pH was achieved, then dried at 90 °C overnight and grounded in an agate mortar. A blank sample was added where FeY was sonicated at the modification conditions (pH=5) without adding extra iron to the suspension (apart from that introduced by the ion exchange), called FeY0. The preparation and nomenclature of all the samples used for the screening experiments are mentioned elsewhere [16]. In brief, the ultrasonic-assisted modified FeY zeolite was named according to the Fe cations introduced to the zeolitic suspension, when at 1 % of divalent (II), a molar ratio of 1:1 of divalent/trivalent cations (II/III) or trivalent (III) the label was FeYII, FeYII/III and FeYIII. When Fe was introduced at a pH=9 the labels were FeYII9, FeYII/III9 and FeYIII. Another set of samples modified at pH=5 with less Fe (0.5 wt%) the samples were referred to as FeY0.5II, FeY0.5II/III and FeY0.5III. 2.2 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity was evaluated in a batch reaction; for the screening experiment, the POBP was assessed by placing 10 mg of the sample in 1 mL of solution with a benzene concentration of 5000 ppm at 90 °C for 30 min. After the reaction time, the catalyst was removed by centrifugation at 10,000 rpm for 10 min at 5°C to quench. UV-Vis then measured the residual amount of benzene in the supernatant at 255 nm. Subsequently, the phenol yield was quantified using a colorimetric reaction with FeCl3, measuring the violet phenoxide complex formed at 428 nm. Calibrations for benzene and phenol were done with 7-point linear regressions ranging from 5000–0 ppm, linear model parameters for benzene with intercept = 0, slope = 3.9189 ± 6.13 E−4 and Adj. R2 = 0.9985. As for the phenol model, the parameters were as follows: intercept = 0, slope = 3.4677 ± 4.522 E−5, and Adj. R2 = 0.9988. The sample presenting the highest potential for the POBP was used in an optimization experiment to determine which factors are essential to predict the conversion ( X C 6 H 6 ) and selectivity ( S C 6 H 5 OH ) for POBP, carried out by a response surface methodology (RSM). The RSM consisted of a 16-run optimization design with three factors and three levels: temperature (5, 40, and 90° C), time (5, 15, and 30 min), and catalyst concentration (5, 10 and 15 mg), denoted as a, B and C, respectively. The reaction procedure in the optimization was carried out as detailed in the screening experiment. The design of the experiment (DOE), analysis of results, and 3D surface and perturbation plots were performed on a Design Expert V13 software. Finally, a recycling experiment was done under the optimal conditions shown in the RSM plot, where the mixture was placed under reaction conditions, calling the first run as 0. Then, after removing the supernatant, the catalyst was washed with excess water by centrifugation in triplicates, dried, and reused in a second run (1). This process was repeated for up to three more runs, yielding runs 2, 3, and 4. To evaluate whether α-Fe is the active site, the reaction was repeated at 30 ºC, and the contaminant concentration was reduced to 1000 ppm of benzene. To confirm the presence of phenol and detect by-products of the POBP, the last run of the recycle analysis and reaction at 30 ºC were separated and detected employing gas chromatography coupled to a mass spectrometer (GC/MS). At the end of the reaction the solid phase (catalyst) was removed by centrifugation (maximum speed for 1 min at 5 ºC). The liquid phase of all reactions were extracted twice with dichloromethane, using 1 mL of solvent per 1 mL of reaction mixture. Once mixed, the dichloromethane was separated and dried with Na2SO4 (enough until no further agglomeration is seen), filtering the solution through a 0.2 μm pore diameter syringe filter. The mass spectra were obtained by an electron impact ionization technique in a Thermo Scientific Gas Chromatograph model TRACE 1310 coupled to a Thermo Scientific single quadrupole mass spectrometer model ISQ LT, where 3 µL of the sample were injected, with the injection port at 250 ºC. The furnace temperature was 70 °C and the ion source 240 °C, with the transfer line at 250 °C. The heating ramp of the column in the furnace started at 70 ºC, maintaining this temperature for 3 min, rising at a speed of 40 ºC min−1 to 280 ºC, and kept at this temperature for 7 min. A flow rate of 1 mL min−1 was used, with a split of 20. 2.3 Characterization The morphology and particle size distributions of the samples were obtained by analyzing grains using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) obtained on a JEOL JIB-4500 equipment (MA, USA), as well as chemical analysis was performed using X-ray dispersed energy spectroscopy (EDX). Particle size distribution data was obtained by treating the images using ImageJ software. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed using an Aeris Panalytical (Malvern, UK) apparatus, equipped with monochromatic radiation Cu Kα (λ=0.154056 nm, 40 kV, 15 mA), diffractograms were analyzed in Highscore Plus software from Malvern Panalytical, to obtain the cell size. Which were used to calculate the framework Si/Al ratio [45]. The chemical composition of the samples was evaluated by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), using a Vista-MPX CCD matrix (CO, USA) simultaneously with ICP-OES (Varian) (CO, USA). An amount of material of 25–50 mg was weighed and mixed with 2 mL of HNO3 and 1 mL of concentrated HF; the mixture was left for 24 hours at 40 °C under static conditions in an oven. Subsequently, 40 mL of 2 % H3BO3 was added to the solution and returned to 40 °C for five hours. Before measurements, all samples were diluted with a factor of 25/1 before the measurements. The measured concentration (mg/L) was converted to molar concentration and subsequent atomic % (at%). The derived chemical formulae for all samples are derived from the framework SAR calculated from the XRD data, and the spare Al was taken as extra framework Al2O3. X-ray emitted photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed with SPECS equipment using a hemispherical PHOIBOS 150 WAL analyzer (DLD, HSA3500) and a μ-FOCUS 500 X-ray source (Berlin, Germany) with Al Kα monochromatic X-ray radiation (photon energy 1486.6 eV, 110 W). The step energy for the survey was 150 eV, with steps of 1 eV. For windows of C 1 s, O 1 s, Si 2p, Al 2p and Fe 2p, it was 50 eV with steps of 0.1 eV. These data were processed with CasaXPS software, and a quadratic Savitzky Golay function (SG) of width 5 was applied. The energies of the spectra charges were calibrated at 285 eV with the C 1 s peak of adventitious carbon. The relative sensitivity factors (RSF) and transmittance factors (TF) used were provided by the manufacturer and are available in the SPECSlab Prodigy software. Likewise, the escape depth (ED) correction was carried out considering the adventitious carbon layer. The Tougaard baseline was used for all orbitals except for Fe 2p, where a Shirley-type baseline was used. All binding energies used for deconvolution were obtained from the NIST X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy Database. Quantification of Fe species was performed by deconvolution method considering only multiple splitting of the 2p3/2 peak, binding energies, FWHM, and limiting to 3 species was done according to the literature [46–48] by selecting three species using an iterative process that best predicts the peak profiles. Ultraviolet-visible (UV-Vis) diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) measurements were done using a UV-Vis NIR Cary 5000 over a 200–1200 nm wavelength range. Infrared spectra were obtained using a Thermo Scientific IR Nicolet IS10 ATR FTIR spectrometer. The band gap was calculated by applying the Kubelka–Munk (KM) function to the UV-Vis spectra. In the case of UV–VIS and FTIR spectra, deconvolutions were performed to obtain the presented center and area. The areas and centers of the resulting curves were used to quantify differences and correlations, considering a p-value <0.05 to be significant. Loss of water and ammonia, as well as decomposition products of the samples, were determined by a Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA; TA Instruments, QA-600) conducted in a range of 40–650 °C with a ramp of 20 °C min−1 under an Ar atmosphere. A magnetic thermogravimetric analysis (MTGA) was employed to measure the magnetic response and response profile on a temperature gradient performed with a model Q5000 TA thermobalance equipped with a permanent magnet over the same temperature range (40–650 ºC) with a ramp of 10 ºC min−1 under Ar atmosphere. The magnetic response of the sample was recorded as the increase in weight from the attractive force of the sample to the magnetic force generated once the magnet was turned on after registering the weight of the sample as 100 %. Zeta potential measurements were obtained using a Zetasizer Nano ZS from Malvern Instruments, programmed to take three automatic readings with no pauses between measurements, equilibrated at 25 °C. Samples were resuspended in deionized water at room temperature by sonication in an ultrasonic bath for less than 5 min. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm measurements were used to determine the textural properties of the materials at −196 °C, with P/P0 values of 0–0.99, in a TriStar II 2020 Micromeritics device. The materials were degassed at 300 °C in a vacuum for five hours. The Langmuir equation was used to calculate the specific surface area (S a ) and NLDFT for the cumulative pore volume (V p ) from the saturation point (P/P 0 ∼ 0.99). A t-plot was used to model the micropore area and volume (S micro and V micro ), and NLDFT was used for the micropore size distribution. The mesopore area (S meso =S a -S micro ) and volume (V meso =V p -V micro ) were obtained from the difference between the total and micropore values. The mean pore diameter (D P ) and the presence of cavitation were calculated using the Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic partial oxidation of benzene to phenol 3.1.1 Screening During screening ( Fig. 1), X C 6 H 6 was observed in all samples due to benzene adsorption and phenol yield [49]. However, the differences allowed us to exclude from the study those samples where the X C 6 H 6 were altered in comparison to the parent zeolite. Given that a modified X C 6 H 6 adds complexity to understanding benzene adsorption, complicating the comprehension of the active site of interest. For this study, an ideal catalyst, when treated with Fe, should increase phenol yield and preserve the mass transfer, diffusion and adsorption of benzene compared to that of the pristine zeolite Y [14]. With these conditions, any change in phenol concentration would be attributed only to a Fe-centered active site. Hence, discarding the samples modified with 1 % of Fe at pH 9 (FeY09, FeYII9, FeYII/III9 and FeYIII9) and pH 5 modified in the presence of a single type of Fe ions (FeYII and FeYIII) due to lower X C 6 H 6 . Likewise, excluding those samples that converted more than the parent zeolite Y (>75 %), being samples modified with a concentration of 0.5 % Fe with a single type of Fe ion (FeY0.5II and FeY0.5III). Positioning as potential candidates for the POBP the samples in which X C 6 H 6 was 75± 3 % (FeY, FeY0, FeY0.5II/III and FeYII/III). Selecting these samples increases the probability of assuring the occurrence of the first three steps of the heterogeneous catalytic reaction (1. Mass transfer to the catalyst, 2. Diffusion into pores and 3. Adsorption), attributing the differences in the later steps (4. Reaction, 5. Desorption, 6. Diffusion from pores, 7. Mass transfer into liquid) to the added Fe active sites. Hence, although these samples are more complex catalysts, the zeolite-benzene interactions are preserved, securing further insight into understanding the reaction mechanism by focusing on S C 6 H 5 OH . The following obvious consideration is S C 6 H 5 OH , whereby inspection, the Fe exchanged Y zeolite at pH 3 (FeY) holds Fe active sites for the oxidation of benzene-to-phenol and further sono-assisted modification with both divalent and trivalent Fe in an NH4NO3 buffer at pH 5 (FeYII/III) enhanced the catalytic activity. The FeYII/III sample outperforms the selected candidates' list by generating 50 % more phenol. Revealing higher S C 6 H 5 OH for the POBP, suggesting that the active sites in FeYII/III make it a more efficient catalyst [50]. Selecting FeYII/III as the best candidate for this reaction. 3.1.2 Optimization by a response surface methodology (RSM) In the reaction optimization experiment ( Fig. 2), the factors with significant effects on X C 6 H 6 for FeYII/III catalyst displays as the central factors temperature ([a], p=0.0004), catalyst concentration ([C], p=0.0014), and the interaction between [a] and time ([a*B], p=0.0010). In contrast to the pristine zeolite Y, with only [a] (p=0.0033) as a significant effect, the introduction of Fe to the zeolite increased the power of the model for manipulating X C 6 H 6 . On the other hand, for S C 6 H 5 OH , the factors with significant effects in the pristine zeolite Y were [a] (p=0.0004), and time ([B], p<0.0001), [B*a] (p=0.0102), and [B*C] (p=0.0237), where all effects depend either on time or temperature. As for FeYII/III, in addition to [a] (p=0.0012), [B] (p=0.0338), the catalyst concentration ([C], p=0.0259) and [C*B] (p=0.0394) significantly influenced S C 6 H 5 OH . Therefore, the applied sonochemical-assisted procedure promoted the introduction of active centers that significantly affect the X C 6 H 6 and S C 6 H 5 OH of the POBP. When analyzing the perturbation plots ( Fig. 3) of the FeYII/III sample, none of the three factors exhibited a volcano-like plot. This means that following the Sabatier principle, where the optimum reaction rate is governed by the interaction strength between the catalytically active surface and the adsorbate [51], the absence of an optimum reaction rate at the tested conditions these are unsaturated and serves to simulate the reaction successfully. For modeling X C 6 H 6 , temperature (a, green line) exhibited an apparent linear correlation, hinting at an external and internal diffusion-sensitive mechanism assisting in the first and last two catalytic steps that occur primarily through mass transfer. As for S C 6 H 5 OH , the same mass transfer effect is detected, however the contribution of time (B, blue line) and catalyst concentration (C, gray line) increased. Showing that S C 6 H 5 OH is an active site-dependent reaction where time and temperature (similar curve shape with change in slope steepness) assist in the adsorption and desorption, where the catalyst concentration affects the reaction itself. At the peak conditions tested (15 mg of catalyst, 30 min, and 90 ºC), the model predicts a first-order reaction with a half lifetime (t1/2) of 27.4840 and 24.0259 min for the elimination of benzene and production of phenol, respectively. Given the nature of the catalyst, multiple framework and extraframework Al species, Fe species and local zeolitic environments with water can assist the catalysis of the POBP, making it complex to measure the turnover frequency due to the lack of information on a specific number of active sites. Yet, the specific activity (SA) at these conditions was 28.89 moles g−1min−1, converting over the time of 30 min, ∼52 moles of benzene, where only ∼13 moles of phenol are diffused into the aqueous solution, giving a reaction with maximum X C 6 H 6 and S C 6 H 5 OH of ∼ 83.4 and 25.4 %, respectively. 3.1.3 Recycle and phenol confirmation When performing a five-run recycling test ( Fig. 4 A), no statistically significant differences (p<0.05) were found in each subsequent run, confirming that the prepared catalyst can be reused, preserving X C 6 H 6 and S C 6 H 5 OH at least five times. However, when the product of the last run was extracted with dichloromethane to separate and detect side products by GC/MS, the X C 6 H 6 and S C 6 H 5 OH were 39.08 and 91.37 % for Y zeolite (Figs. 4B) and 73.25 and 91.50 % for FeYII/III (Fig. 4 C), respectively. Measuring higher values for both samples than those obtained from the colorimetric assays. By subtraction of the amounts in bulk (adsorbed in the catalyst and solvated in the solvent) and solvated (adsobed=bulk-solvated), 18.27 moles of benzene and 21.49 moles of phenol are adsorbed on the surface of the Y zeolite, leading to an overestimation of conversion and underestimation of selectivity. When only analyzing the liquid phase by the colorimetric assay the SA of Y zeolite was 6.3 molg−1min−1 in contrast to 49.9 molg−1min−1 when measuring from the bulk. Revealing that the parent zeolite can adsorb benzene and oxidize it to phenol, the exact mechanism remains to be elucidated. Nevertheless, a synergistic mechanism is proposed given that BAS are known to adsorb benzene [52] and vicinal Lewis Acid Sites (LAS) with high acid strength could generate the oxidation [53]. CBV 500 is known to have BAS and LAS with high acid strength [17], thus providing a versatile path towards the reactivity of zeolite materials. These acid sites were explored and strongly correlated (p<0.05) with the conversion and selectivity for the POBP (Figure S1). However, these LAS in the parent sample (CBV500), formed from the steaming treatment generating extraframework Al (EFAl) species, are not fully understood, and multiple species have been proposed [54]. Since not all synthesized phenol diffuses to the aqueous solution, the EFAl active site that converts benzene to phenol is poisoned, forming a Lewis acid abduct such as an aluminum phenolate. Upon contact with dichloromethane, this Аl-phenolate dissociates, assisting the diffusion to the liquid phase, explaining the increase of phenol and benzene content measured from GC/MS. On the other hand, the sonochemically Fe-modified zeolite (FeYII/III) showed the same effect of adsorbing benzene (6.05 moles) and phenol (28.97 moles). Lowering the amount of adsorbed benzene (Δ=-12.22) and increasing that of phenol (Δ=7.48), favoring benzene desorption and phenol adsorption. Despite the enhanced phenol adsorption, the X C 6 H 6 and S C 6 H 5 OH for the POBP was increased, with a SA=38.8 molg−1min−1 at 90 ºC when measuring only the liquid phase and 93.8 molg−1min−1 when extracting and measuring the bulk. These changes hint at a shift in active site from an Al to a Fe center, favoring the oxidation to phenol as well as the desorption and diffusion. According to the perturbation plots, increasing any of the three factors evaluated enhances the formation of phenol. However, increasing any conditions influences the reaction mechanism and, possibly, the by-product distribution. For example, increasing the catalyst concentration could saturate the liquid medium, promoting catalyst agglomeration and limiting mass transfer. Equally, a rise in temperature would promote solute and solvent evaporation, having a false positive effect. It could also allow the activation of secondary pathways, compromising the reaction itself. For these reasons, to investigate if the catalytic center was the room temperature α-Fe active site, the initial concentration of benzene was reduced from 5000 to 1000 ppm ( Fig. 5), lowering the reactant: catalyst ratio and increasing the amount of available active sites per benzene molecule. Along with this reduction in benzene concentration, the reaction temperature was lowered from 90 ºC to 30 ºC to enhance the activation of the α-Fe active site and limit any other active site that would lead to secondary benzene oxidation routes. Given that at 30 ºC, the measured X C 6 H 6 (90.75 %) and S C 6 H 5 OH (99.86 %) increased with a SA=126.9 molg−1min−1 compared to that at 90 ºC (SA=93.8 molg−1min−1), the room-temperature catalytic center for the selective oxidation of benzene to phenol was linked to α-Fe/O. The proposed mechanism (Fig. 5D) arises from benzene adsorption to an α-O active site, where an NIH shift is the crucial step for phenol desorption and, if not occurring, poisoning the active site. If phenol desorption is achieved, the α-Fe can follow a single turnover or regenerate the α-O through a water nucleophilic attack (WNA). The exact mechanism for the promoted phenol desorption and LAS assisting the WNA regeneration are still to be elucidated, needing a further understanding of the dynamic effect of water and EFAl species in zeolite catalysts [53–55] and testing different solvents with different polarities in different water/solvent ratios to optimize the reaction. There is no doubt that this α-Fe/O site is present, given the formation of phenol at room temperature. This active site anchored on ZSM-5 was first discovered in the study in a gas phase N2O decomposition ( Table 1), coupling this reaction with the selective oxidation of benzene to phenol at high temperatures [26,27,56]. Later, finding that this α-Fe/O site can form in different zeolites and selectively oxidize many hydrocarbons at room temperature, including benzene [57]. The most widely accepted studies for the hydroxylation of benzene to phenol involve a gas phase reaction [22,38], yet many other studies have also detected this oxidation in liquids [20,21,29]. These reactions employ acetonitrile and H2O2 as the oxidant, and even though poor X C 6 H 6 and dihydroxybenzene isomers (C6H6O2) are by-products, high S C 6 H 5 OH can be obtained. However, this acetonitrile/H2O2 reaction did not take place with FAU due to poor catalyst resuspension, in contrast to the water/H2O2 system where high selectivities were achieved [21]. A disadvantage of these water/H2O2 reactions is that phenol can be hydroxylated when increasing the amount of peroxide [20]. Hence, given that peroxide species hydroxylate phenol and the poor interaction of FAU and benzene in acetonitrile, a reaction where no H2O2 and mainly water is used for the hydroxylation of benzene over α-Fe/O sites is a promising area of research. This should be further investigated since these α-sites have been prepared through steaming [58] and are known to react with water [59]. 3.2 Characterization Even though the proposed active sites still need to be fully understood in the literature, the following characterization gives an insight into the EFAl and Fe species present in the prepared catalyst. Visual inspection of the SEM micrographs ( Fig. 6) reveals no apparent high contrast between the structure of the zeolite and deposited Fe species, suggesting a high dispersion of Fe species on the zeolite particles. Due to the absence of brighter spots denoting differences in atomic numbers given the higher Z value of the Fe atoms [66] and supporting the catalytic activity due to the high Fe species dispersion. Adding to the high dispersion, in all the samples, the particles present similar shapes with no significant difference in the crystal size distribution (p=0.1640), as expected for an ultrastable Y zeolite according to the literature [6,19,66,67]. Nevertheless, sonicating the zeolite, compared to the non-sonicated samples (Y and FeY), generated a narrowing effect in the particle size distribution with increased outliers detected. This narrowing phenomenon and shifting to higher particle size distribution is attributed to the ultrasonic irradiation-promoted deagglomeration effect at nanometric scales [68]. Thus reducing aggregation of particles and creating micro-level disruptions in the zeolite framework, facilitating access to internal pores and creating a more uniform zeolitic material. Hence these slight changes in the particle size distribution explain the desired unaltered X C 6 H 6 , compared to the parent Y zeolite [65]. The proposed high Fe dispersion was reinforced by only detecting the parent faujasite zeolite CBV500 (JCPDS 00–038–0240) from the diffraction patterns ( Fig. 7 A). Indicating that when performing ion exchange (FeY) and sonicating the FeY zeolite in a controlled pH=5 ammonia buffer (FeY0) with dissolved Fe ions (FeYII/III) does not amorphized the faujasite structure and the introduced quantities of Fe are not in a detectable concentration crystal state. Nevertheless, the preserved crystal structure presented minor unit cell dimension changes associated with expansions and contractions, attributed to desilication and dealumination, caused by the changes in the Si/Al ratio of the zeolite framework [69]. This known cell size relationship [45] is based on the longer Al-O bond distance (1.73 Å) compared to the Si-O length (1.63 Å). Allowing the detection of dealuminations (cell contraction) and desilication (cell expansion) [44,70] from the calculated Si/Al ratios in the crystalline framework, which serve as a starting point for the detection of the EFAl species participating active sites for the POBP. This change in framework Al was corroborated by the existing correlation with the distance between the binding energies of the Si 2p and Al 2p peaks measured from the photoelectrons generated in the XPS analysis (Fig. 7B). According to the well-known linear trend, the difference in these binding energies (ΔBE=Si 2p-Al 2p) is a function (Fig. 7 C) of the zeolites framework Al content [71]. Comparing these changes in the ΔBE=Si 2p-Al 2p with the mole fraction of Al in the framework (obtained from the XRD data) confirms that this ratio is the framework Si/Al ratio (SiF/AlF). This suggests that when sonicating the zeolite, the Al atoms transition to more stable states in the presence of the Fe ions, verified by comparing the Si/Al ratios measured using different techniques. This comparison of the different Si/Al values obtained from the different techniques confirms the Al gradient in the parent zeolite Y, and the applied treatment modifies this gradient. When analyzing the Al atomic % calculated from XPS (surface) and EDS (bulk), a shift in the gradient is seen from an 18 at the surface and 12 percent in bulk (surface/bulk of 18/12 at%), to a 12/10 at% in the samples with added Fe. The already present Si/Al ratio gradient of the parent dealuminated zeolite (CBV500) formed during steaming contains stable Al-rich zones [45,72]. These Al-rich zones protect the Si/Al gradient when introducing the Fe by sonication ( Table 2), as seen from the stable surface and bulk Si/Al ratios. The differences in the surface, bulk and structural Si/Al ratios denote the presence of EFAl species from the increased Al content at the surface. This surface Al species could assist the catalytic oxidation of benzene to phenol when no Fe is present or assist Fe α-O active site reactivity or regeneration (Fig. 5D), explicitly promoting the NIH shift or by accepting electrons, respectively. These framework and extraframework species were further quantified from the XPS spectra deconvolutions of the Si 2p and Al 2p windows. Exhibiting from the Si 2p ( Fig. 8 A) non-bonded oxygen (NBO) species being framework associated and extraframework aluminosilicate species, which can serve as active sites for the adsorption or oxidation of benzene. Likewise, in the Al 2p orbital (Fig. 8B), the Aln+ are also EFAl-related species, where the Al3+ species would be framework species forming the cationic sites that, if the configuration is correct, create potential α-Fe sites. The chemical formula was obtained by coupling the obtained framework ratios (XRD data, mentioned above), complemented with the ion-exchanged cations, adding the corresponding Fe ions quantities measured from the EDS and ICP data ( Table 3), compensating the charge with NH4 + ions. These NH4 + counter ions were used, given that the parent zeolite (CBV500) was exchanged with ammonium ions, and the Fe treatments were employed in ammonia buffers. Surface speciation obtained from the XPS data was added to complement the framework and ion exchange chemical formula, gaining insight into the difference in framework and extraframework species and corroborating the above-mentioned EFAl species. It is worth noting that the observed discrepancies in Fe content between EDS and XPS measurements arise from the differing surface sensitivities of these techniques, XPS primarily detects Fe in the near-surface region, whereas EDS provides a bulk measurement. These discrepancies in Fe content further support the presence of an Al gradient, as the distribution of Fe species is influenced by the charge balance requirements of both framework and extraframework Al. Equally from the XPS, the multiplet deconvolution of the Fe 2p3/2 served to quantify the surface Fe speciation (Fig. 8D). Where three iron species were identified (Fe(II) ions, Fe(III) ions and FeOOH) from an iterative work guided by the Fe species data from the literature (details in the methods section) and the amount of oxygen corresponding to Fe from the O 1 s deconvolution. Detecting the changes in Fe speciation and surface loading (Table 3), exhibiting that from the ion exchange process (FeY), 8.7 at% of Fe is deposited on the surface, and further sonication (FeY0) increased the Fe content to ∼14 at%. This increase suggests a sono-assisted desilication since no extra Fe is added to FeY when sonicated (FeY0, blank sample). This sono-assisted process influences the content in Fe species while conserving Al-rich zones of the zeolitic framework, promoting the subtraction of extraframework Al, Si and amorphous aluminosilicate species. This substraction process has been reported elsewhere [45,72], and although the mechanism is not yet fully understood, some insight from theoretical calculations proposes that the main reactions taking place are hydrolysis reactions [73]. Furthermore, in the ion exchange (FeY sample), FeII is oxidized to FeIII, and these ions form Fe2O3 and FeOOH. When ultrasound is applied to this Fe exchange faujasite (FeY) in an ammonium buffer at pH 5 (FeY0), the Fe species equilibrium shifts towards FeOOH, eliminating from the surface the ions corresponding to Fe2O3. When adding 1 wt% of Fe (in a 1:1 molar ratio mixture of FeII: FeIII ions) to the solution buffer at pH=5 (FeYII/III), more ions that form Fe2O3 and FeOOH are stabilized on the surface as expected from the increase of available Fe in solution, increasing the percentage of Fe from 8.7 % to 11.8 %. Maintaining the seen sono-assisted equilibrium shift towards FeOOH, as mentioned above. These observed changes suggest that Fe, water and zeolitic bonds create a complex interaction that needs further study to understand and elucidate the catalytic relationship fully. In addition, in sample FeYII/III it was also seen an apparent framework protection effect unaltering the SiF/AlF ratio, suggesting that the presence of Fe ions impacts the dealumination and desilication of the zeolite structure [18,74,75]. Given the evidence that the zeolitic bonds are dynamic and have a reversible feature that allows Si-O-Al bonds to be reversibly hydrolyzed in the presence of water [76], further investigation on the effect of Fe and zeolite desilication/dealumination mechanisms is suggested considering: (I) the convergence of reversible evolution of zeolites [76], (II) dynamic evolution of Fe species in zeolites [22,30,31,34–36,77], (III) Al distribution in FAU structures [78] and (IV) the proposed dealumination mechanisms from the literature [73]. Supporting these statements, contrary to the classical view of zeolite as a static, rigid, and changeless material, recent studies have found that the T−O−T bonds of zeolites could be reversibly broken and formed, showing dynamic and reversible features. However, these interactions are complex since the H2O molecules inside zeolites possess distinct structures compared to those in an environment without confinement [54,55,79–82]. In general, the evolution of framework atoms and foreign metals in zeolites is strongly dependent on the reaction conditions (e.g., temperature, pressure, and steam/reductive/oxidative/acid/base atmosphere) and the nature of the zeolites (e.g., topology, Si/Al ratio, and crystallinity). It is necessary to change the classical concept of zeolites as static and solid materials with the novel belief that, to some extent, zeolites are dynamic, labile, and flexible under practical reaction conditions [76]. To further elucidate the different Fe species in the samples, light absorption from UV−Vis Diffuse Reflectance Spectroscopy [83] served to detect alterations in the site geometry or nuclearity of charge-transfer Fe complexes. This is achieved, by employing the second derivative method to outline the several curves that convolute the spectrum, making this technique suitable for semiquantitative analysis of Fe composition and geometry. Judging from the optical response using UV-Vis DRS ( Fig. 9), when deconvoluted, the differences indicate a wide distribution of several Fe species, with the differences observed in the spectra being due to relative differences in the concentrations of iron species in octahedral and tetrahedral coordination [84], clusters [85], nanoparticles [29], oxides [18,29,84], and their size and arrangement. Characterization of iron species and forms in these samples is limited due to peak overlaps and the complexity of the iron species chemistry. Thus, some uncertainty remains in the association of the formed active sites with the spectra [50]. Nevertheless, according to deconvolution analysis, changes in the spectra of the samples are ascribed to different amounts of tetrahedral Fe(III), octahedral Fe(III), FexOy clusters on the inner surface, FexOy clusters on the outer surface, FeOx nanoparticles, α-Fe (II) and isolated Fe(II) cations. These associations are not exclusive, as several aspects of the observed Fe species distribution need to be considered. For small iron oxide particles, the center of the excitation is correlated with their size [86], meaning that shifts can occur superimposing with transitions of α-Fe. In samples with iron oxide particles, reddish color is seen along with a pair of excitations with a broad band centered at ∼830 nm and a second sharp lower wavelength band [30,34,86]. For α-Fe, the center of the band can shift depending on the local environment with a broad excitation, ranging from ∼470–950 nm [30,31,34,77]. For framework Fe(III), when no other form of Fe is present, small sharp excitations centered at 373, 413, 438, and 480 nm are resolved, accompanied by two superimposed excitations centered around 330 and 200 nm [30]. In connection with this last consideration, in samples saturated with α-Fe, it is assumed that the broadening in the region of ∼900–1200 nm is suspected with the presence of small clusters and isolated Fe(II) ions not in the α-Fe(II) geometry [30,31]. Together with other characterization techniques, these centers were linked to a specific Fe species by quantifying the area percentage ( Table 4). In addition, Fe(III)-OH is characterized as a photoactive catalytic center that activates Fe(IV)=O, under which the α-O structure is formed [24]. These centers are active under UV light [87,88], which agrees with the band gap shift observed in the Fe modification of Y zeolites obtained with sono-activation. Due to the low Fe concentration in the samples, no Fe species were detected in the FTIR spectra (Fig. 9B). Nevertheless, subtle changes compared to the parent USY zeolite ( Table 5) reveal: bulk Si/Al, framework Si/Al (SiF/AlF), cations in SIII, SII, SI’ and SIII’ exchange sites, α-Fe, and adsorbed species (H2O, NO3 -, NH4 +, NO2, and HNO3). These associations are made from the changes measured in the centers and areas of the peaks obtained from the deconvolution of the spectra (Fig. 9B and Table 5). From which in the pseudo lattice vibration range, an increase in the framework Si/Al ratio (SiF/AlF) shifts the center of the νs of D6R and Si-O-T to higher wavenumbers [89,90] where the vibration at 657 cm−1 are known to be sensitive to Fe2+ [89,91–93]. These sensitive vibrations to Fe2+, where also found to correlate with the conversion (%), where more Fe would decrease the amount converted (Fig. 1S). On the other hand, the bulk Si/Al ratio calculated from the TO4int vibration is maintained. In contrast the selectivity (%) was seen to increase with the acid strength of the BAS (∼1640 cm−1) and decrease when more water interacts with the SI’ cation exchange site (∼3600 cm−1). Equally, in the OH vibration range, the changes suggest that the Fe ions are mainly in the cation exchange sites of SII and SIII’ [94–98]. From these data, we can conclude that when Fe is present in specific D6R sites, conversion and selectivity is affected. A unique role is played by N2O-activated Fe zeolites, where so-called α-Fe/α-O sites are generated after thermal annealing in a reducing atmosphere, correlating with the amount of Brønsted sites probed with NO, and isolated Fe species quantified from UV-Vis spectra [28,83,99]. These α-Fe/α-O active sites have been proposed to be detected by MTGA [16] due to the increase in weight around 300ºC, attributed to the paramagnetic ground state of α-Fe(II) when in a square planar molecular geometry [22,77]. The proposed mechanism for this detection involves the decomposition of the adsorbed NH4NO3 at ∼300 °C to H2O and N2O [19,100,101] transforming this latter into α-O and N2 [34,36]. In the FeYII/III sample, the transition was observed at 338 ºC ( Fig. 10A), confirming the presence of α-Fe/α-O sites. The detected mass loss from these TGA experiments showed a positive correlation (p=0.0169) with the shift of the center of the NH4 + vibrations (∼1450 cm−1), which are associated with α-Fe [16]. This is expected since the α-Fe models bind to 6 member rings through two framework Al atoms [22,32,34] where different molecules such as H2O and NH4 + [45] and NO3 - can be adsorbed [100]. Further reacting in the zeolite microenvironment can produce dynamic evolutions of Fe species, interconverting Fe oxides to mononuclear sites by controlling the reactant atmosphere and temperature [76]. The same dynamic phenomenon can occur for NH4 + and the associated BAS, functioning as counter ions balancing the Al charge in the zeolite where no Fe is present [53,78,102]. Given that the surface is mainly modified with FeOOH, the zeta potential (ζ) was measured to gain knowledge of the surface charge (Fig. 10B). Reflecting the degree of protonation/dissociation of the surface hydroxyl groups from Fe-OH and Al-OH, given that at the tested neutral pH, Si-OH does not dissociate [103]. Shifting the ζ to a more negative charge increases the amount of surface Fe in the modified Y zeolite. Equally, this change in charge could also arise from the decrease in particle size due to the increase in the surface-to-volume ratio [104], increasing the metal oxide surface species (Fe or Al) [105,106]. In addition, silanol nests are excluded [107] due to their absence, as seen from the FT-IR spectra. Hence, the average charge (eV) is attributable to specific species observed by XPS, a surface-sensitive technique, such as surface FeOOH and Al species. These data were corroborated by deconvolution of the Al 2p and Fe 2p window, where a surface enrichment is detected with the combination of Al species, FeOOH and Fe ions [45,72]. According to the textural properties, CBV500 exhibited a type-IV isotherm ( Fig. 11 A) [108], with an H2(b) hysteresis loop associated with pore blocking and a broad pore neck width distribution [109]. The pore architecture of this commercial zeolite has been characterized in detail and is composed of a channel-like structure of mainly micropores and restricted mesopores with an occluded and constricted pore network that develops within the sample, blocked by extraframework debris [110]. Equally, this network connectivity has pores with a neck width smaller than the critical neck width (5–7 nm) causing cavitation, evidenced by the abrupt drop in adsorption near 0.5 P/P0. This cavitation was confirmed by comparing the pore size distribution obtained from the adsorption and desorption branches of the isotherm (data not shown) calculated using the BJH method [109] which also confirmed the opened partially restricted pores in all the samples [108–110]. Comparing the FeY sample with Y, the pore architecture is maintained, however, more mesopores are formed (Fig. 11B). Hysteresis reveals a higher level of pore blocking, which is detected and corroborated by the increase in the desorption branch artifact peak, representing more N2 evaporation when cavitation occurs. When the FeY sample is sonicated in the absence of Fe at pH 5, more mesopores are formed, indicating the reduction of pore blocking. In contrast, pore blocking is promoted when sonicating the FeY zeolite in the presence of divalent and trivalent Fe (FeYII/III sample), as seen from the mesopore reduction. This is supported by the evaporation of even more N2 at the cavitation stage, denoting a slight constriction of the pore network and, thus, a narrower neck width. The parent USY zeolite has two principal micropore distributions with mean diameters of 1.24 and 1.85 nm (Fig. 11B), which agrees with the theoretical diameter of the faujasite supercage (1.24 nm) and the sum of the diameters of the supercage and the sodalite cage (0.61 nm). As well as mesopores detected above 4.7 nm, this is expected given that this zeolite (CBV500) is subjected to a steaming process and as mentioned above, these mesopores have been characterized in detail elsewhere. When Y undergoes ion exchange, the micropores are unaffected, maintaining the faujasite structure, corroborated by the XRD data. However, the distribution of mesopores widens starting from 3.6 nm (Δ 1.1 nm), with the newly formed pores differing from each other by 0.14 nm, which is approximately half the diameter of the D6R cavity (0.26 nm). When observing the effect of sonication on this Fe-exchanged zeolite, the pore distribution expands in the mesopore range, now starting from 3.2 nm. This broadening occurred in steps with 0.25 of a D6R cavity diameter. Provided that sonicating at pH=5 does not significantly affect the Si/Al ratio, this pore data hints that the slight Si/Al ratio change is associated with the removal of amorphous material. This amorphous material with volumes of 0.25 of that of the D6R cavity diameter might be trapped in the pores, exposing these volumes when sonicating. On the other hand, when sonicating the FeY suspension in the presence of Fe ions, a broadening of the micropores distribution to smaller pore widths denotes the slight pore constriction (mentioned above), suggesting micropore filling. At the same time, blocking the mesopore cavities that emerged when exchanging the zeolite with Fe, as evidenced by the reduction of mesopores, means that Fe ions promote zeolitic pore network changes. Therefore, when sonicating a Fe-exchanged Y-type zeolite, the produced Fe species interact with the zeolite channels, displacing aluminosilicate species and causing the detected dealumination from the Si/Al ratio changes. Likewise, the absence of the mesopores suggests pore-filling or a rearrangement of the zeolitic structure without affecting micropores and, thus, the faujasite structure. Due to the nature of the catalysis process, changes in the pore architecture can be beneficial for the POBP reaction. When applying ultrasonic irradiation, there is a trend associated with the selectivity and surface area, in particular with the micropores (Table S1). On the other hand, the conversion was seen to be more pore size dependent. Nevertheless, in this sonoassisted Fe modifed Y type zeolite (FeYII/III), the slight changes had no statistically significant effect at a p<0.05. The observations outlined in this study are based on dynamic properties, fast bond breaking and formation, transformation of the metal valence state, phase evolution, and metal migration in the metal-zeolites [76]. This is due to the structural versatility of the various Al species present in zeolites [53], reflecting that zeolites are non-static inert materials. Instead, the T−O−T zeolite bonds are dynamic and can be reversibly broken and formed under certain reaction conditions [76]. Furthermore, the spatial confinement of H2O afforded by zeolite pores coupled with the catalytically active sites in a dynamic framework needs further study to enable the full potential of zeolites as tunable, unique shape-selective catalysts and specific chemical product synthesis [111]. 4 Conclusions Modifying commercial Y zeolite with Fe species using a sono-assisted method shows the potential for creating active Fe sites capable of catalyzing the selective partial oxidation of benzene to phenol at room temperature. Employing sonication to modify zeolite Y in NH4NO3 buffer with Fe allows the stabilization of α-Fe, making possible the catalysis reaction under accessible conditions such as ambient pressure, temperature below 100 ºC and short reaction time such as 30 min. This active site in the Fe-modified Y zeolite catalyst was found to be stable when reused at least 5 times, under the tested conditions, maintaining the X C 6 H 6 and S C 6 H 5 OH . Given that no intermediates nor side products were detected by gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (GC/MS), the reaction mechanism suggests the activation of a single main pathway. Nevertheless, further investigation is required to improve the catalyst efficiency and enhance phenol desorption due to the observation of active site poisoning. This work suggests that a sono-assisted method for introducing Fe to zeolite Y produces an active site that can oxidize benzene to phenol at room temperature using water as a solvent. Opening new opportunities for tuning and improving Fe-based zeolite catalysts under mild reaction conditions in which the active site is α-Fe. coredata.dc:description: Enzyme-mimetic materials such as Fe-containing zeolites are of research interest due to the high selectivity for the one-step selective oxidation of benzene to phenol over the Fe-catalytic active center at room temperature and ambient pressure. This study investigates a Fe-modified Y zeolite catalysts prepared via a sonochemical method for the oxidation of benzene-to-phenol using water as solvent. These catalysts were subjected to a screening and optimization experiment by a response surface methodology (RSM), evaluating their potential for the synthesis of phenol. Achieving the preparation of a catalyst with an increased phenol selectivity from 3 % to ∼91 % and almost 100 % when evaluated at 30 ºC. Various Fe species, including the α-Fe(II) active site, were detected using UV-Vis spectroscopy, FTIR spectroscopy, and magnetic thermal gravimetric analysis (MTGA). Highlighting the potential of sonochemistry for preparing at mild temperatures (<100 ºC) iron-modified zeolite Y catalysts with room temperature catalytic active in water-based systems.
